subSense.def:
with natural
curves or twists
subSense.example: curly hair

subSense.def:
the money
used in a specific country
subSense.example:
I want to
change my pounds into French curren-
cy

subSense.def:
relating to
the present time
subSense.example:
What is the current
state of the report -will it be finished on
time?

Who is the current prime minis-
ter of Japan?

Do you have a current
timetable? -mine is out of date

subSense.def:
widely accepted at the present time or at
a particular time
subSense.example:
current ideas about
how to treat children

The idea that the
world was flat was current in the Middle
Ages

subSense.def: a flow of water or air
subSense.example:
Don't go swimming in the river -the
current is very strong

A warm wester-
ly current of air is flowing across the
country

Vultures circle in rising cur-
rents of warm air

subSense.def: a flow of electricity
subSense.example: Switch the current off at the mains

subSense.def:
at the
present time
subSense.example:
He is currently the man-
ager of our Paris office

We are cur-
rently in the process of buying a house

subSense.def:
the
set of subjects studied in school
subSense.example:
I am
very glad that music and drama have
been added to the curriculum

body.subSense:
2. the
parts of a particular subject that are
studied (NOTE: [all senses] The plural is
curriculums or curricula.)

an Indian food pre-
pared with spices ć I would like a mild
curry, please. ć We ordered chicken
curry and rice. (NOTE: The plural is cur-
ries.)

subSense.def:
a small flashing
line on a computer screen which shows
where the next character will appear

a long piece
of cloth hanging in front of a window
subSense.example: Can you close the curtains, please?

subSense.def:
a
long piece of cloth hanging in front of
the stage at a theatre

a line that is bent like
part of a circle
subSense.example:
the curve of the coast
line

subSense.def: to be in the shape of a curve
subSense.example:
The road curves round the side of the
mountain

subSense.def:
with a rounded
shape

a bag filled
with something soft, e.g. feathers, for
sitting or leaning on
subSense.example:
Put a cushion be-
hind your back if you find your chair is
too hard

subSense.def:
to make soft something
which could be hard or painful
subSense.example:
The
bushes cushioned his fall
subSense.re:
to cushion
somebody or something from some-
thing to protect someone or something
from the bad effects of something

to
cushion the blow or the shock to re-
duce the bad effect of something that
happens ć She made no attempt to cush-
ion the blow, but just told them straight
out that they had all lost their jobs

body.subSense:
1. something
that people usually do, or have done for
a long time ć the local custom of deco-
rating the wells in spring ć It's their
custom to invite all their neighbours to a
party at New Year

subSense.def:
the use of a shop
or restaurant
subSense.example:
If the assistants are rude
to me again I will take my custom else-
where
subSense.re:
to lose someone's custom to
experience a situation in which a regular
customer goes to another place of busi-
ness, e.g. a restaurant or shop ć The lit-
tle shops will lose a lot of custom when
the new supermarket opens

body.subSense:
usu-
al (formal) ć He handled the situation
with his customary efficiency. ć It's cus-
tomary to give taxi drivers a tip

subSense.def:
a person
who buys something in a shop or restau-
rant, or from another business
subSense.example:
The
shops are lowering their prices to at-
tract more customers

Customers can
order by post on or the Internet

His
bar is always full of customers

subSense.def:
a per-
son who uses a service such as a train
subSense.example:
We apologise to customers waiting on
Platform 5 for the late arrival of their
train

subSense.def:
to divide, reduce or re-
move something using a sharp tool, e.g.
a knife or scissors
subSense.example:
The meat is very
tough -I can't cut it with my knife

He
needs to get his hair cut

There were
six children, so she cut the cake into six
pieces

subSense.def:
to damage the skin with some-
thing sharp
subSense.example:
She cut her finger on the
broken glass

He cut himself while
shaving

body.subSense:
3. to reduce the size of some-
thing ć We are trying to cut the number
of staff. ć Accidents have been cut by
10%. ć The article is too long, so I
asked the author to cut 500 words.
(NOTE: cuts -cutting -cut -has cut)

subSense.def:
a place which bleeds when
your skin has been broken

a mark
made in a surface by something sharp

the sudden lowering of the amount of
something
subSense.example: price cuts

large cuts in
spending
a cut in working hours

subSense.def:
a
share of something such as profits
subSense.example:
Each salesperson gets a cut of what is
sold for cash

body.subSense:
knives, forks and
spoons (NOTE: no plural)

subSense.def:
a summary of some-
one's qualifications and experience

a period during
which something develops and then re-
turns to its starting point
subSense.example:
Global
warming is starting to affect the natural
cycle of the seasons

The washing ma-
chine broke down in the middle of its cy-
cle

subSense.def: a bicycle

body.subSense:
to travel on a bi-
cycle ć It's hard to cycle into the wind.
(NOTE: cycles -cycling -cycled)

subSense.def:
a person who
rides a bicycle

an object
shaped like a tube closed at both ends

the fourth letter of the al-
phabet, between C and E
a father

body.subSense:
a newspaper pub-
lished every weekday (NOTE: The plural
is dailies.)

subSense.def:
referring to or in-
volved in producing milk and things
made from it such as cream or butter
subSense.example: dairy products
dairy cattle

subSense.def:
a wall which blocks a
river to make a lake
subSense.example:
After the heavy
rain people were afraid the dam would
burst

body.subSense:
to block a river with a wall
ć When they built the power station, the
river had to be dammed. (NOTE: dams -
damming -dammed)

1. the break-
ing or physical spoiling of something ć
The storm did a lot of damage. ć It will
take us months to repair the damage to
the restaurant. ć The fire caused dam-
age estimated at £100,000

subSense.def:
emotional
harm done to a person
subSense.example:
I hope the ex-
perience of the crash won't cause the
children lasting damage

subSense.def:
to
break or partially destroy something
subSense.example:
A large number of shops were damaged
in the fire

These glasses are easily
damaged

subSense.def:
to affect someone or some-
thing in a negative way

broken
or spoiled in some way
subSense.example:
a damaged
book

subSense.def: slightly wet
subSense.example:
She'd just had a shower and her hair
was still damp

The cellar has cold
damp walls

subSense.def:
to wet something
slightly

a way of moving
in time to music
subSense.example:
She teaches dance or
is a dance teacher

We learnt a new
dance today

Scottish dances are very
lively

subSense.def:
an entertainment where people
can dance
subSense.example:
The club is holding a New
Year's dance

They met at a youth club
dance

subSense.def:
to move in time to mu-
sic
subSense.example:
There he is -he's dancing with
that tall girl

She often goes to discos
but never dances

subSense.def:
to move or jump
around happily
subSense.example:
She danced into the
room and announced she'd got the job

The football fans were dancing in the
streets

subSense.def:
a person who
dances

the possibility
of something bad happening, e.g. dam-
age, failure or getting hurt
subSense.example:
When it
rains, there's a danger of flooding

The terrorist was described as a danger
to national security

There's no dan-
ger he'll find out

We were warned of
the dangers of travelling alone in the
desert

subSense.def: likely to cause injury or damage
subSense.example:
Be
careful -that old staircase is danger-
ous!

Police warned the public not to
approach the man as he was dangerous

Children are warned that it is danger-
ous to go out alone at night

subSense.def:
in
a dangerous way
